html: 4.28.24  11:49 am   i have this fascinating issue where maybe 9/10 times I hear some kind of lyrics or words in a song i fall down this tunnel of thinking about where they originated, how the artist felt, why they phrased it that way, how it must have come about in the writing stage, etc until it just becomes totally overwhelming and I can't listen anymore cause it hits the inside part very hard. maybe a case of "how is this even possible" itis. is there a cure for this y/n and if n how do I Deal with it

4.27.24  9:54 pm   Your voice is so smooth, it's quite beautiful. Your drumming is always so creative and your synth playing oh my GOSHHH. Your works are nothing short of genius and I just want to say thank you, THANK YOU for posting these. I honestly don't know where I'd be without them. Your bass playing matches beautifully with the other sections. Listening to "if the world doesn't end" followed by "fly around" is like being hugged and told it'll be alright. I can't say thank you enough. Thank you for making them, thank you for posting them, THANK YOU for doing what you do. Your songs absolutely touch my soul in ways I can't describe and fill me with hope even on the worst of days. Once again: thank you.

4.27.24  11:18 am   lately ive been haunted by the notion that an instrumental song cant stand on its own (like it needs some other thing to go along with it).
so i tried making songs with lyrics and i suck at it, and ive been sucking at it for quite a while now.
but whenever i try to write a song w/o lyrics i think about that notion again and it ruins the whole thing.
so i think i have to either use that thought to help me make lyric songs until im good at it, or i conbince myself its not true and just make more instrumentals.
until i decide im in music limbo where i cant finish anything. do you have any thoughts on that original notion i mentioned at the start? or on the situation or whatev
